content:
• Monday, March 13, 2017
  • ON

    ON Semiconductor proposes $500M convertible senior note private offering

    • To be due 2023, notes are for exclusive offer among qualified institutional purchasers. Option (30-day) for sale of additional $75M aggregate principal amount also granted to initial buyers.
    • Proceeds are intended for repayment of outstanding debt under term loan B facility and payment of associated transaction fees and expenses.
    • ON Semiconductor (NASDAQ:ON) $15.05, -1.7% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:02 PM | 9 Comments
  • BB

    Analyst: BlackBerry could see comeback via infrastructure projects

    • BlackBerry (BBRY +2.6%) may be poised for a comeback, Global Equities Research suggests, and the unlikely benefactor may be the priorities coming from the new presidential administration.
    • Analyst Trip Chowdhry reiterated an Overweight rating noting that the company is in good position for a central role in $1 trillion in proposed infrastructure spending.
    • “BBRY can be the intelligent infrastructure system provider for the new collar industry" -- next-gen jobs that are a hybrid of blue collar and white collar -- "which we think could be 10% of [a] $200 billion infrastructure spend, or $20 billion,” Chowdhry says.
    • Aside from that development, which needs a 2-3 year horizon, quarterly numbers mean "nothing," Chowdhry says.
    • Chowdhry has an $11 price target, implying 57% upside from today's close.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:37 PM | 92 Comments
  • ICON

    Iconix Brand Group affiliate sued for $90M in damages

    • A lawsuit has been filed against Iconix Brand Group (NASDAQ:ICON) affiliate Umbro IP Holdings in the state of New York by Premier Goal Club and Balanced Tech Corp.
    • The action alleges that Iconix breached trademark licensing arrangements with respect to the Umbro trademark and entered a new licensing agreement with a major retailer unjustly.
    • The plaintiffs are asking for an award of compensatory damages of just under $90M combined.
    • Filing with the New York court system
    • Shares of Iconix fell 2.70% today.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:29 PM | 152 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: RT +20.7%. MNKD +4.6%. INAP +4.3%. EQGP +2.9%. REN +2.4%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: AUPH -17.4%. TLYS -12.9%. VRX -10.0%. AMPH -5.0%. DOC -3.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 3 Comments
  • DRWI

    DragonWave rises double digits on Australia distribution pact

    • DragonWave (DRWI +9.5%), recently the subject of volatile trading, is up 17.4% in light postmarket action after announcing a distribution deal with Ingram Micro Australia.
    • The new master sales and services agreement will have Ingram Micro expand its vendor portfolio to the Australia channel, introducing DragonWave's packet microwave product portfolio -- particularly the Harmony Enhanced MC, suited for high-bandwidth rural connectivity, the company says.
    • "Ingram Micro will help launch our new Harmony Enhanced MC product line into very important channel markets where wireless networks are playing an ever-increasing role to augment ongoing National Broadband Network fiber builds," says DragonWave CEO Peter Allen.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:12 PM | 11 Comments
  • CSCO

    Needham boosts Arista price target on new software strategy

    • Arista Networks (ANET +2.7%) has an advantage in its software strategy that gives it an edge on rival Cisco Systems (CSCO -0.5%), Needham says.
    • The firm boosted its price target on Arista to $150 from $130, implying near-18% upside from today's close.
    • A "containerized" EOS operating system allows for running on white box hardware, part of a strategy that "really matters to the Web 2.0 customers; Cisco Systems can't match it," writes Needham's Alex Henderson.
    • The two companies are awaiting an ITC hearing in April tied to ongoing patent litigation.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:02 PM | 5 Comments
  • LNTH

    Lantheus readies stock offering by existing shareholders; shares ease 1% after hours

    • Lantheus Holdings (NASDAQ:LNTH) slips 1% after hours on light volume in response to its announcement of a public offering of common shares from existing stockholders. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced. The company will receive no proceeds from the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM | 3 Comments
  • BHC

    Ackman bails on Valeant; shares off 8% after hours

    • Long-time Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) bull Bill Ackman has apparently waved the white flag. CNBC reports that he sold 27.2M shares at ~$11 and will be quitting the board. Developing....
    • Shares are down 8% after hours on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM | 699 Comments
  • RT

    Strategic alternatives at Ruby Tuesday shares up 15%

    • The company has retained UBS to assist.
    • Alongside, preliminary FQ3 results (ended Feb. 28) show same-store sales down about 4%.
    • RT +14.9%
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM | 65 Comments
  • TLYS

    Tilly's down 10% after dour outlook

    • The company topped Q4 estimates, but says quarter-to-date comp sales, including e-commerce sales have fallen by a high single-digit percentage thanks to a later Easter and significant weather issues in CA, AZ, and NV.
    • Management expects Q1 comp sales to be down by low-to-mid single-digit percentage, operating loss of $3M-$7M, and loss per share of $0.07-$0.15 vs. $0.10 loss in FQ1 of 2016.
    • Conference call at 4:30 ET
    • Previously: Tilly's beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (March 13)
    • TLYS -9.9% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM

    Aurinia readies equity offering; shares ease 8% after hours

    • Aurinia Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:AUPH) slips 8% after hours on robust volume in response to its planned public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 36 Comments

    Anthera Pharma launches equity offering; shares drop 28% after hours

    • Anthera Pharmaceuticals (OTC:ANTH) slumps 28% after hours on increased volume in response to its announcement of a public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be released.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 5 Comments

    Physicians realty Trust -4% on capital raise

    Citrix Systems +7.3%; work with Goldman Sachs involving exploration of sale reported [updated]

  • LJPC

    LaJolla Pharma under pressure on questions about LJPC-501's mortality benefit; shares slip 2%

    • La Jolla Pharmaceuticals (LJPC -1.9%) has been the red almost all session. According to BioCentury, doctors are questioning the efficacy of treatment-resistant hypotension candidate LJPC-501 (angiotensin II). Last month, the company announced the successful outcome of a Phase 3 study, ATHOS-3, assessing LJPC-501 for the treatment of a life-threatening drop in blood pressure called catecholamine-resistant hypotension (CRH). The trial met its primary endpoint of demonstrating a statistically valid proportion of patients who achieved a target blood pressure response.
    • Clinicians, however, are keen to know LJPC-501's effect on mortality, which ATHOS-3 could not show since it was not powered to do so.
    • LJPC-501 is a proprietary formulation of angiotensin II, which acts to stabilize blood pressure and help the kidneys balance body fluids and electrolytes.
    • Previously: La Jolla's angiotensin II successful in late-stage study; shares ahead 73% (Feb. 27)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 PM | 3 Comments

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: OTC:PRKR +-17%. CRDS +-14%. NCR +-11%. SUNW +-11%. OTC:TNGO +-8%.
    • Losers: OTC:PRKR -17%. CRDS -13%. NCR -10%. SUNW -10%. OTC:TNGO -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:04 PM | 3 Comments
  • RIG

    Transocean extends gains as may be near $1.2B deal to sell 15 rigs

    • Transocean (RIG +1.9%) is up another 2% after Friday's similar gain, which apparently was sparked by reports that it was near a deal for a $1.2B sale of its fleet of shallow-water rigs.
    • The potential deal reportedly would include RIG’s entire active fleet of 10 high-specification jack-ups plus another five newbuilds under construction for a total $1.2B; excluding the $290M already paid for the newbuilds, Evercore ISI's James West says the reported purchase price averages to $120M/jackup and is well above its bull case estimate
    • Evercore says it would be "aggressive buyers" of RIG if the deal materializes, as it would monetize an under-utilized jackup fleet that averages 13.5 years of age and eliminate a large chunk of future newbuild capex.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM | 28 Comments
  • GE

    GE's lagging performance not all Immelt's fault, J.P. Morgan analyst says

    • General Electric (GE -1.6%) is giving back most of its Friday gains that were sparked by a Fox Business report that CEO Jeffrey Immelt is "in the hot seat" with Nelson Peltz and his Trian Fund.
    • GE shares have lagged the market for the past 15 years, advancing just 0.4% annually including reinvested dividends vs. a 7% return for the S&P 500, and Barclays discussed an unnamed investor’s view that the stock could gain 5% from a CEO change, along with various other reasons to like the stock.
    • But J.P. Morgan's Stephen Tusa thinks the stock has struggled not because of execution or something the CEO has done wrong, but "because of the stubbornly low growth and secular challenges embedded in end markets where a company of this size is forced to play, as evidenced by limited profit growth despite $8B of restructuring and significant gains since 2012."
    • Even so, Tusa prefers Danaher (DHR -0.6%), which "gets a multiple because it generates cash and redeploys into growth from a base of revenue that is 15% of what GE is, and recently even shrunk the portfolio to reset the growth trajectory."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:41 PM | 41 Comments
  • GST

    Gastar Exploration ready to buy after last week's 24% drop, Canaccord says

    • Buy the dip in Gastar Exploration (GST +1.6%), as the stock is oversold after falling 24% last week and is set to build momentum later this year and beyond, analysts at Canaccord Genuity say.
    • The firm notes GST is the only pure Mid-Continent player in Oklahoma, where it has more than 80K net surface acres with 1K-plus net STACK locations, and $425M in new financing from Ares Management cleans up the balance sheet and pushes out 2017-18 debt maturities until 2022, helping give the company more flexibility to prove out its core STACK acreage.
    • Meanwhile, Canaccord says the new development agreement positions GST to minimize leasehold renewal costs with minimal drilling capital on the company's part, while maintaining the majority of the upside.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:21 PM | 8 Comments
  • SPWH

    Sporting goods sector stirred up again by bankruptcy

    • Credit Suisse thinks Sportsman's Warehouse Holdings (SPWH +0.2%) will benefit from the Gander Mountain bankruptcy to a larger degree than Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS -3.7%).
    • The Gander bankruptcy is the largest in the sporting good sector since Sports Authority filed. Gander generated sales of $1.32B last year.
    • Previously: Gander Mountain said to be close to bankruptcy filing (Feb. 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM | 3 Comments

  • BHP

    BHP tries again to get Escondida mine union to resume negotiations

    • BHP Billiton (BHP +2%) is inviting striking workers at its Escondida copper mine in Chile to return to the negotiating table, after a similar approach was rejected on Saturday.
    • BHP addressed the workers' grievances in a letter sent to the 2,500-member union, which says it is analyzing the letter to determine its response.
    • Escondida, the world's largest copper mine, produced a bit more than 1M metric tons of copper in 2016; it is majority owned by BHP, with Rio Tinto (RIO +3.4%) and Japanese companies including Mitsubishi holding minority interests.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:58 PM
  • INTC

    Intel -1.8% following $15.3B bid for Mobileye

    • Although certain strategic advantages of an Intel-Mobileye combination are evident (greater autonomous vehicle technology capacity, potential processor and vision system synergies etc.), concerns over deal pricing as well as accounting, sharp competition (most notably Nvidia), acquisition track record, talent retention and other execution related items are factoring into present sentiment. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) $35.28, (MBLY +29%).
    • Earlier (March 13, 2017): Intel confirms acquisition of Mobileye
     
     
     
     
    | 1:46 PM | 31 Comments

  • SPOT

    Pandora CEO: Company's not for sale and is headed for profit this year

    • After the company announced its new premium subscription service, Pandora Media (P +0.6%) chief Tim Westergren says the company isn't for sale and will fulfill a tall order in 2017: profitability.
    • Several stock moves in past months have been attributed to commentary from Liberty's Greg Maffei about whether Sirius XM (SIRI +6.2%) would buy Pandora.
    • "These are early days in the subscription of music and listeners don't know what a real premium product looks like yet and that's what Pandora is," he told CNBC. No one (meaning rivals Spotify (MUSIC) and Apple Music) has really solved the ease-of-use problem for subscription music, he says.
    • As for headroom on marketing spending against deep-pocketed competitors, Westergren said "it starts with our listener base," suggesting Pandora can get the word out on the platform for free.
    • Pandora lost $343M last year.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:08 PM | 88 Comments
  • STM

    STMicroelectronics components selected for Nintendo Switch inclusion

    • Comprising STMicroelectronics' motion sensors, touch-screen controller IC, STM32 microcontrollers and NFC controller IC, the contribution is notable, especially as prior involvement with Nintendo's Wii is held by STMicroelectronics in particularly high regard.
    • STMicroelectronics (NYSE:STM) +0.29%, +2% intraday.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM | 5 Comments
  • ADAP

    Adaptimmune top-line up 112%; pipeline advancing; shares ahead 15%

    • Adaptimmune (ADAP +15%) Q4 results ($M): 8.5 (+111.8%).
    • Net Loss: (15.4) (+8.3%); Loss/Share: (0.04) (unch); Cash Flow Ops (12 mo.): (48.2) (-52.5%).
    • 2017 Guidance: Quick assets of $181.5M (as of 12/31/16) should be sufficient to fund operations through mid-2018.
    • Results beat consensus views.
    • Initial data on MAGE-A10 and MAGE-A4 T-cell therapies expected later this year. Four open INDs, including three SPEAR T-cells.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:50 PM | 12 Comments

  • SALT

    Scorpio Bulkers up another 6% after upgrdae

    • A doubling in the stock price over the past six months isn't scaring off Credit Suisse's Gregory Lewis, who upgrades to Outperform from Neutral.
    • "Asset prices continue to melt-up with each transaction," he says.
    • Bulker prices are up about 30% since bottoming about a year ago, and with "nil modern tonnage" available, he expects prices to grind higher.
    • The new price target of $10 suggests about another 25% upside.
    • SALT +5.9% to $8.10.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • OSIR

    Trading in Osiris Therapeutics to be suspended tomorrow, formal delisting to follow; shares slump 19%

    • Osiris Therapeutics (OSIR -18.8%) continues its down move on more than 7x higher volume. Shares have lost over 45% of their value since last week when the company announced that Nasdaq will suspend trading in its stock starting tomorrow. The exchange will also proceed with a formal delisting, effective 10 days after it files a Form 25 with the SEC.
    • After tomorrow, the stock will be quoted on the Pink OTC Markets ("pink sheets").
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM
  • TPB

    Turning Point Brands rallies after earnings

    • Turning Point Brands (TPB +6.8%) moves higher after Q4 revenue came in ahead of estimates.
    • Smokeless products sales for the year increased 4.9% to $77.9M, driven higher by the growth of Stoker moist smokeless tobacco.
    • Stoker MST cass shipments were up by approximately 7% Y/Y.
    • Overall demand was impacted during the quarter by a new $0.55 per ounce excise tax in Pennsylvania, which became effective on October 1.
    • Previously: Turning Point Brands EPS of $0.87 (March 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:17 PM
  • ARLZ-OLD

    Aralez Q4 top-line shy of consensus; shares slump 29%

    • Aralez Pharmaceuticals (ARLZ-OLD -28.6%) Q4 results ($M): 20.0 (+233.3%), consensus: 23.1.
    • Product revenues: 6.4; revenues from Toprol-XL and Zontivity: 8.6; VIMOVO royalties: 5.0.

    • $6.8M non-cash expense for amortization of intangible assets associated with Tribute, Zontivity and Toprol-XL plus $4.4M impairment charge related to Tribute intangible assets.

    | 12:03 PM | 3 Comments

    Citron Research commends Mobileye takeover by Intel

    • Having communicated shift of short positioning in Nvidia to Mobileye (MBLY +29.5%) less than a month ago (though negative on shares for years), firm remains mystified over deal pricing at approximately 30x 2017 revenue (as well as over volume of shares sold by management over public life of the company), though concedes it's "undoubtedly Mobileye's day."

  • XL

    XL Group -1.8% after downgrade

    • Following about a 20% run higher in the stock over the past few months, Sandler O'Neill's Paul Newsome downgrades XL Group (XL -1.8%) to Hold from Buy, and cuts the price target to $41 from $46.
    • Reinsurance markets remain very soft, he says, and he expects XL is set to benefit less than peers from tax reform.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM
  • DXLG

    Destination XL Group spikes, Canada expansion planned

    • Destination  XL Group (NASDAQ:DXLG) is up 17% after a mid-morning spike on strong volume.
    • The company announced that it's entering the Canadian market with a DXL Men's Apparel store opening in Toronto. A second Canadian store is planned for April.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:49 AM
  • PTE

    Shareholders OK Majesco Entertainment/PolarityTE combination

    • Shareholders have given final sign-off on a merger between Majesco Entertainment and PolarityTE (COOL +6.9%), finalizing the videogame maker's transition toward a medical tissue company.
    • More than 99% of the represented 3,368,498 shares approved of the deal.
    • It's a "significant milestone" for the companies, says Chairman/CEO Denver Lough: "We look forward to closing this merger and focusing exclusively on building Polarity into its full potential and beyond."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM | 5 Comments
  • HLTH

    Nobilis misses on Q4 earnings, net income down 71%; shares slip 19%

    • Nobilis Health (HLTH -19.2%) slumps on more than a 4x surge in volume after it released Q4 results. Revenues beat consensus by almost $3M but EPS fell short by nearly 43% ($0.12 versus consensus of $0.21).
    • Q4 numbers ($M): Revenues: 101.9 (+13.2%); Net Income: 13.6 (-71.2%); EPS: 0.12 (-79.3%).
    • CEO Harry Fleming says, "Although we are pleased to report strong total revenue growth of 25% for full year 2016, we are disappointed that we did not meet the profitability goals we set out to achieve for the year. Full year Adjusted EBITDA was impacted by higher than expected marketing expenses and overall operating expenses.  As we enter 2017, we will continue our mission to provide high quality surgical procedures across all of our brands and markets.  We expect that the progress we have made integrating recently acquired facilities, coupled with the efforts to better target our marketing dollars and reduce certain operating expenses will support the strategic and financial goals for 2017."
    • 2017 Guidance: Revenues: $310M - 325M; Non-GAAP EBITDA: $40M - 45M.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM | 8 Comments
  • GES

    Wunderlich still positive on Guess

    • Wunderlich isn't throwing in the towel on its bullish view of Guess (GES -1%), despite the sharp drop in share price from a year ago (-47%).
    • "While we fully admit that the domestic side of GUESS?'s business, like virtually every one else, remains highly challenged, we believe investors are ignoring multiple signs of a turn in the key (and higher-margin) European and Asian businesses, which have the ability to drive overall upside for the company," reads the firm's note.
    • Wunderlich has a Buy rating and $20 price target (+67% upside) on the retailer.
    • Shares of Guess yield 7.55% to new buyers.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:14 AM
  • GPRK

    GeoPark +10% after J.P. Morgan says Buy on exploration success

    • GeoPark (GPRK +10.3%) surges as much as 31% to its highest since November 2014 after J.P. Morgan upgrades shares to Overweight from Neutral with a $10 price target, double the firm's previous $5 target.
    • JPM says GPRK's proved exploratory success in Colombia increasing 2P reserves by 46% Y/Y, increased production expectations and sound free cash flow generation in 2017-18 are the main reasons supporting the upgrade.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:08 AM
  • NLS

    Nautilus +2% after Imperial Capital upgrades

    • Imperial Capital boosts its rating on Nautilus (NLS +2.1%) to Outperform from In-line on what the firm calls "compelling" valuation.
    • The underleveraged balance sheet and free cash flow potential at Nautilus are seen as positive drivers for share price.
    • The investment raises the price target on the fitness products seller to $20 from $16.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM | 5 Comments
  • DLPH

    Delphi Automotive rallies off of Intel-Mobileye news

    • Shares of Delphi Automotive (NYSE:DLPH) are up 3.05% in morning trading.
    • The company has partnerships with both Mobileye and Intel, two companies which announced a disruptive merger earlier today.
    • Previously: Intel confirms acquisition of Mobileye (March 13)
    • Previously: Select stocks on watch after monster Intel-Mobileye deal (March 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM
  • TRGP

    Targa Resources upgraded to Buy from Hold at Stifel

    • Targa Resources (TRGP +1.9%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $65 price target, inched up from $64, at Stifel, citing TRGP's leading Permian gathering and processing footprint that supports volumes across its Gulf Coast natural gas liquids assets.
    • Stifel also says commentary at Enterprise Products Partners' recent analyst day supported its belief that domestic LPG export volumes will remain solid.
    • Given that Stifel's fundamental thesis on TRGP has only strengthened, the firm believes the stock's recent pullback presents an attractive entry point for investors.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:43 AM | 6 Comments
  • BHP

    Global miners move higher as China affirms capacity cuts

    • China's steel and iron ore futures resume their climb overnight, surging a respective 5.9% and 4.3%, after the head of China’s Ministry of Information and Technology reaffirmed the government’s resolve to cut excess capacity in the steel sector.
    • Today's strength also is attributed to seasonal demand, as Chinese construction activity picks up after a slowdown over winter.
    • Among relevant tickers: SLX +2.4%, BHP +2.1%, RIO +3.5%, VALE +4.1%, CLF +4%, X +3.9%, MT +4.2%, AKS +3%, WOR +2.7%, FCX +2.3%, TECK +2.6%, AA +2.4%, CENX +1.7%, ACH +1.2%, KALU +1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:24 AM | 19 Comments
  • ROX

    Castle Brands pops after company presentation

    • Castle Brands (NYSEMKT:ROX) is up 12% after the company presents at the 29th Annual Roth Conference.
    • Management points out that Castle Brands trades at 2.7X revenue vs. the 5X-6X multiple typically seen with public drinks companies.
    • Castle Brands investor presentation
     
     
     
     
    | 10:08 AM | 7 Comments
  • FATE

    Fate Therapeutics cleared to begin clinical trial assessing NK cell therapy in blood cancer; shares up 9%

    • Thinly traded micro cap Fate Therapeutics (FATE +9.4%) jumps out the blocks on more than a 6x surge in volume in response to its announcement that the FDA has approved its Investigational New Drug (IND) application for FATE-NK100, an adaptive memory natural killer (NK) cell product. The approval paves the way for a first-in-human clinical trial in patients with advanced acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
    • The early-stage study, to be conducted at the University of Minnesota, will determine the maximum tolerated dose of a single intravenous administration of FATE-NK100 in an accelerated dose escalation design in four patients.
    • FATE-NK100 is a next-generation immunotherapy based on a subset of NK cells that have shown robust anti-tumor activity in addition to promoting endogenous T cell response while resisting immune checkpoints.
    • NK cells identify and kill cancer cells by recognizing a range of stress signals expressed on tumor cells. Normal healthy cells are unaffected/unharmed. This is a different mechanism of action compared to T cells which require a specific tumor antigen to elicit an immune response and must be customized for each patient. The company says a significant advantage of NK-based immunotherapy is the avoidance of graft-versus-host disease, a common and potentially serious side-effect of T cell therapies.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:59 AM | 2 Comments
  • GNRT

    Post-earnings rally for Gener8 Maritime

    • Gener8 Maritime (GNRT +9.7%) breaks higher after the company tops Q4 estimates.
    • The full fleet TCE rate for the quarter was $28,190 vs. $40,236 last year.
    • Net voyage revenue was flat compared to last year at $99.6M.
    • Previously: Gener8 Maritime beats by $0.07, beats on revenue (March 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:57 AM | 1 Comment
  • NAV

    Icahn boosts stake in Navistar to 17%

    • Carl Icahn has raised his stake in truck maker Navistar (NAV +3.4%) to 17.02%, according to an SEC filing.
    • That was up from the 16.61% stake the company previously reported as of February 28.
    • Last week, Navistar reported a much wider-than-expected quarterly loss on continued industry weakness, but said its new product line is positioned well for an expected market rebound in the second half of 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:37 AM
  • WYNN

    Morgan Stanley sees positive trends for Wynn Resorts

    • Morgan Stanley backs up it bullish call on Wynn Resorts (WYNN +3.6%) in a fresh note issued this morning. The best case scenario from MS has Wynn doubling in share price to $200, while the one-year price target is $119.
    • "Macau gaming revenue rose 10% in 4Q16, and 11% YTD. We expect high-single-digit growth going forward. The growth is being driven by spend per visitor recovering rapidly, a demographic shift that plays into WYNN's premium positioning," writes analyst Thomas Allen.
    • A dig into Google trends shows a huge uptick in searches for Wynn's properties since the opening of Wynn Palace. The long-term potential of the Boston project also plays into Morgan's thesis.

  • Amgen's Repatha reduces need for apheresis in patients with high "bad" cholesterol in late-stage study; shares ahead 1% premarket

    • Results from a Phase 3 clinical trial showed patients with abnormally elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) who were receiving apheresis to lower their levels of "bad" cholesterol significantly reduced their need for the plasma-cleansing procedure by taking Repatha (evolocumab).
    • The study involved 39 patients with LDL-C levels between 100 mg/dL and 190 mg/dL (optimal is less than 100 mg/dL) despite undergoing apheresis once or twice per week. They were randomized to receive either Repatha every two weeks or continue apheresis for six weeks. After the six-week period, all received Repatha.
    • Detailed results will be submitted for publication and for presentation at an upcoming medical conference.
    • Shares are up 1% premarket on light volume.

  • HTBX

    Heat Biologics advances HS-110 to Phase 2 development; shares jump 56% premarket

    • Nano cap Heat Biologics (NASDAQ:HTBX) rockets 56% premarket on average volume in response to its announcement of successful results from a Phase 1b study assessing the combination of HS-110 and Bristol-Myers Squibb's (NYSE:BMY) Opdivo (nivolumab) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study met is safety endpoint by demonstrating no new toxicities compared to existing data on nivolumab alone. In addition, 33% of patients (n=5/15) experienced at least a 20% reduction in tumor size.
    • Daniel Morgensztern, M.D., Associate Professor of Medicine and Director of Thoracic Oncology, Washington University School of Medicine says, “We are encouraged by the results from this Phase 1b trial evaluating the therapeutic vaccine, HS-110, combined with the checkpoint inhibitor, nivolumab, in patients with advanced NSCLC. We continue to see that the combination appears to be generally well-tolerated, and the encouraging signs of efficacy warrant a larger sample size. We’ve seen some patients with increased tumor infiltrating lymphocytes after treatment, and anticipate that we can confirm this trend in the Phase 2.”
    • The results are good news for stockholders. Shares plummeted in December after lead product candidate HS-410 failed to beat placebo in a mid-stage bladder cancer study.
    • Previously: Heat Biologics' lead product candidate flunks mid-stage bladder cancer study; shares plummet 56% (Dec. 1, 2016)
